content.text: Define gravitational field strength
Assuming that the comet has constant density, calculate the gravitational field strength on the surface of the comet
field strength =   .........  Nkg\({}^{-1}\)
A probe having a weight of \(960 \text{N}\) on Earth lands on the comet
Using your answer in (i), determine the weight of the probe on the surface of the comet
weight =   .........  N
The mass of a spherical comet of radius \(3.6 \text{km}\) is approximately \(1.0 \times 10^{13} \text{kg}\)
A second comet has a length of approximately \(4.5 \text{km}\) and a width of approximately \(2.6 \text{km}\). Its outline is illustrated in Fig. 1.1
Suggest one similarity and one difference between the gravitational fields at the surface of this comet and at the surface of the comet in (b)
similarity:
difference:
State what is meant by the symbol \(\langle c^2\rangle\)
Use the expression to show that the mean kinetic energy \(E_{\mathrm{K}}\) of a gas molecule is given by
where \(k\) is the Boltzmann constant and \(T\) is the thermodynamic temperature
The pressure \(p\) and volume \(V\) of an ideal gas are related to the density \(\rho\) of the gas by the expression
An ideal gas containing \(1.0 \text{mol}\) of molecules is heated at constant volume

Use the expression in **(a)(ii)** to show that the thermal energy required to raise the temperature of the gas by \(1.0 \text{K}\) has a value of \(\frac{3}{2} R\), where \(R\) is the molar gas constant

Nitrogen may be assumed to be an ideal gas. The molar mass of nitrogen gas is \(28 \text{g} \text{mol}^{-1}\). Use the answer in **(b)**(i) to calculate a value for the specific heat capacity, in \(\text{J} \text{kg}^{-1} \text{K}^{-1}\), at constant volume for nitrogen
A bar magnet of mass \(250\mathrm{g}\) is suspended from the free end of a spring, as illustrated in Fig. 3.1
The magnet hangs so that one pole is near the centre of a coil of wire
The coil is connected in series with a resistor and a switch. The switch is open
The magnet is displaced vertically and then allowed to oscillate with one pole remaining inside the coil. The other pole remains outside the coil
At time \(t = 0\), the magnet is oscillating freely as it passes through its equilibrium position. At time \(t = 6.0 \text{s}\), the switch in the circuit is closed
Explain the main principles behind the use of ultrasound to obtain diagnostic information about internal body structures
A parallel beam of ultrasound has intensity \(I_0\) as it enters a muscle of thickness \(4.6 \text{cm}\), as illustrated in Fig. 4.1
The intensity of the beam just before it leaves the muscle is \(I_{\mathrm{T}}\)
The ratio \(I_0 / I_{\mathrm{T}}\) is found to be 2.9
Calculate the linear attenuation (absorption) coefficient \(\mu\) of the ultrasound in the layer of muscle
State two advantages of the transmission of data in digital form rather than in analogue form
Outline the process by which the ADC converts the analogue signal \(\mathsf{S}_{\mathrm{I}}\) into the digital signal D
The ADC and the DAC operate with the same sampling rate and the same number of bits in each digital number
State the effect on the transmitted analogue signal \(\mathsf{S}_{\mathrm{T}}\) when, for the ADC and the DAC,
1. the sampling rate is increased,
2. the number of bits in each digital number is increased

An analogue signal \(\mathsf{S}_{\mathrm{I}}\) is converted into a digital signal D using an analogue-to-digital converter (ADC). After transmission of the digital signal, it is converted back to an analogue signal \(\mathsf{S}_{\mathrm{T}}\) using a digital-to-analogue converter (DAC), as illustrated in Fig. 5.1
State Coulomb's law
Use Fig. 6.2 to explain whether the two spheres have charges of the same, or opposite, sign
A proton is at point P where \(x = 5.0 \text{cm}\)
Use data from Fig. 6.2 to determine the acceleration of the proton
acceleration =   .........  \(\text{ms}^{-2}\)
Two charged metal spheres A and B are situated in a vacuum, as illustrated in Fig. 6.1
The shortest distance between the surfaces of the spheres is \(6.0 \text{cm}\)
A movable point P lies along the line joining the centres of the two spheres, a distance \(x\) from the surface of sphere A
The variation with distance \(x\) of the electric field strength \(E\) at point P is shown in Fig. 6.2
Use data from Fig. 6.2 to state the value of \(x\) at which the rate of change of electric potential is maximum. Give the reason for the value you have chosen
Suggest why, when the capacitor is connected across the terminals of a battery, the capacitor stores energy, not charge
Define the capacitance of the capacitor
The capacitor is charged so that the potential difference between its plates is \(V_0\)
The capacitor is then connected across a resistor for a short time. It is then disconnected
The energy stored in the capacitor is reduced to \(\frac{1}{16}\) of its initial value
Determine, in terms of \(V_0\), the potential difference across the capacitor
potential difference =   .........
A capacitor consists of two parallel metal plates, separated by an insulator, as shown in Fig. 7.1
On Fig. 8.1, draw a circle around the output device
State the purpose of this circuit
State whether blue light or green light is emitted when the resistance of component C is greater than the resistance \(R_{\mathrm{V}}\) of the variable resistor. Explain your answer
State and explain what is observed as the resistance of component C is reduced
The resistors X and Y each have resistance \(R\)
When conducting, the LED labelled B emits blue light and the LED labelled G emits green light
Suggest the function of the variable resistor
A student designs a circuit incorporating an operational amplifier (op-amp) as shown in Fig. 8.1
a Hall probe is made from a thin slice of material,
in order for consistent measurements of magnetic flux density to be made, the current in the probe must be constant
Explain why
The probe is now rotated through an angle of \(360^{\circ}\) about the axis XY
At angle \(\theta = 0\), the Hall voltage \(V_{\mathrm{H}}\) has maximum value \(V_{\mathrm{MAX}}\)
On Fig. 9.2, sketch the variation with angle \(\theta\) of the Hall voltage \(V_{\mathrm{H}}\) for one complete revolution of the probe about axis XY
A Hall probe is placed near to one end of a current-carrying solenoid, as shown in Fig. 9.1
The probe is rotated about the axis XY and is then held in a position so that the Hall voltage is maximum
Briefly describe two phenomena associated with the photoelectric effect that cannot be explained using a wave theory of light
Identify the symbol \(\lambda_0\)
The variation with \(\frac{1}{\lambda}\) of \(E_{\mathrm{MAX}}\) for the metal surface is shown in Fig. 10.1
1. Use Fig. 10.1 to determine the magnitude of \(\lambda_0\)
2. Use the gradient of Fig. 10.1 to determine a value for the Planck constant \(h\)
The maximum energy \(E_{\mathrm{MAX}}\) of electrons emitted from a metal surface when illuminated by light of wavelength \(\lambda\) is given by the expression
where \(h\) is the Planck constant and \(c\) is the speed of light
The metal surface in **(b)** becomes oxidised
Photoelectric emission is still observed but the work function energy is increased
On Fig. 10.1, draw a line to show the variation with \(\frac{1}{\lambda}\) of \(E_{\mathrm{MAX}}\) for the oxidised surface.
Show that the momentum \(p\) of the accelerated electron is given by
State what is meant by the _de Broglie wavelength_
Calculate the de Broglie wavelength of the electron
wavelength =   .........  m
The potential difference \(V\) through which the electron is accelerated is \(120 \text{V}\)
The separation of copper atoms in a copper crystal is approximately \(2 \times 10^{-10} \text{m}\)

By reference to your answer in **(b)**(ii), suggest whether electron diffraction could be observed using a beam of electrons that have been accelerated through a potential difference of \(120 \text{V}\) and are then incident on a thin copper crystal
An electron has charge \(-q\) and mass \(m.\) It is accelerated from rest in a vacuum through a potential difference \(V.\)
Complete the nuclear reaction shown above
Show that the energy equivalent to 1.00 u is 934 MeV
Calculate the binding energy per nucleon, in MeV, of lanthanum-139 ( \(^{139}_{57}\mathrm {La}\) )
binding energy per nucleon =   .........  MeV
State and explain whether the binding energy per nucleon of uranium-235 ( \(^{235}_{92}\mathrm {U})\) will be greater, equal to or less than your answer in (b)(ii)
One nuclear reaction that can take place in a nuclear reactor may be represented, in part, by the equation
